page.title: 5.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn how to write terms that include rational exponents as radicals and vice versa.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Simplify radical expressions with even and odd indexes.
  • Rewrite expressions with rational exponents as roots.
  • Use properties for exponents with rational exponents.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.2.1: Perfect Squares Revisited
  • 5.2.1: Roots and Radicals
  • 5.2.2: The nth Root
    • 5.2.2: Self Check
  • 5.2.3: Radicals and Rational Exponents
    • 5.2.3: Self Check
  • 5.2.4: Properties of Exponents with Rationals

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.2.5: Practice
  • 5.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.2.1: Perfect Squares Revisited
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


  1. What is the value of \(4\;\times\;4\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

16



  1. What is the value of \(4^2\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

16



  1. Using what you know about roots, what is the value of \(\sqrt{16}\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

4


  1. Talk to a partner. How can you prove \(\sqrt[2]{4^2}\;=\;4\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

Since \(4^2\;=\;4\;\cdot\;4\;=\;16\) and \(\sqrt{16}\;=4\), \(\sqrt[2]{4^2}\;=\;4\).

Notice that the root and exponents are the same and simplify to leave the integer only.


  1. Talk to a partner. What do you think the answer to \(\sqrt[5]{4^5}\) would be?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

\(\sqrt[5]{4^5}\;=\;4\)

page.title: 5.2.2: The nth Root
page.contents:
Activity

Work with a partner to discuss and answer the following questions.

  1. Complete the table when \(n=-2\) on your paper and check your answers.

\(n\)

\(n^2\)

\(n^3\)

\(n^4\)

\(n^5\)

–2

        

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:


\(n\)

\(n^2\)

\(n^3\)

\(n^4\)

\(n^5\)
–2 4 –8 16 –32


  1. What do you notice about the answers when the powers are even?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are positive.



  1. What do you notice about the answers when the powers are odd?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are negative.


The \(\sqrt a\), or square root of \(a\), is the same as \(\sqrt[2]a\). What about when we want to take roots that are higher than the square root? These are called radicals.

The nth root, or radical, is written \(\sqrt[n]a\). If \(b^n=a\), then \(b\) is an nth root of \(a\). The \(n\) is called the index of the radical. Just like \(\sqrt[2]n\) is called the square root, \(\sqrt[3]n\) is the cubed root, \(\sqrt[4]n\) is the fourth root, and so on. The number inside the radical is called the radicand.

  1. Using what you did with the powers in number 1, complete the table to find the roots of each.

\(4^3=64\) \(\sqrt[3]{64}=4\)
\(3^4=81\)  
  \(\sqrt[5]{-32}=-2\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:


\(4^3=64\) \(\sqrt[3]{64}=4\)
\(3^4=81\) \(\sqrt[4]{81}=3\)
\({(-2)}^5=-32\) \(\sqrt[5]{-32}=-2\)

Could we have an even root of a negative number? We know that the square root of a negative number is not a real number. The same is true for any even root. Even roots of negative numbers are not real numbers. Odd roots of negative numbers are real numbers.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. Watch the signs of the factor. The answer is –3.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. The answer is –3.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be the result of dividing –27 by 3. Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. The answer is –3.

page.title: 5.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Simplifying Radicals

When simplifying radicals, think which number will be used as a factor the number of times indicated by the index to get the number under the radical.

In the example above,

\(2\;\times\;2\;\times\;2\;=8\), so \(\sqrt[3]8\;=\;2\).

Remember, when the index is odd, the root is allowed to be negative. When the index is even, the root cannot be negative.

Try It: Simplifying Radicals

Simplify.

\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to simplify a radical:


Step 1
Identify the index.
5

Step 2
Identify the radicand (inside the radical).
–32

Step 3
What number can be used as a factor 5 times to get –32?
\((-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)=-32\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;=\;-2\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.2.3: Self Check
page.contents: Rewrite \(\sqrt[10]{x^7}\) as a term with a rational exponent.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 7 is the exponent, and the 10 is the index. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The exponent gets written over the root.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 10 is the root, not a coefficient. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The fraction should be the exponent. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).

page.title: 5.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Simplify \(\sqrt[4]{81}\). Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Simplify \(\sqrt[5]{-32}\). Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.2.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is –2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(\sqrt[4]{x^3}\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x^\frac34\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(\sqrt[9]{2^4}\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(2^\frac49\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Simplify \(k^3\;\cdot\;k^\frac13\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(k^\frac{10}3\). \(k^3\cdot k^\frac13=k^{3+\frac13}=k^{\frac93+\frac13}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Simplify \({(m^\frac34)}^{-2}\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac1{m^\frac32}\). Multiply the exponents, and then get rid of the negative exponent. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. True or false:

    \(\sqrt[4]{-16}\;=\;-2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You cannot take the even root of a negative number and have a real answer. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. True or false:

    \(\sqrt[3]{-64}\;=\;-4\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.2.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is true. The cubed root of 64 is 4, and it is possible to have an odd root of a negative number. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following expressions are equivalent to perfect squares? Select all that apply.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.2.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 25, \(\sqrt{16}\), \(\sqrt[5]{9^5}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \({(x^\frac15)}^4\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x^\frac45\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.2.3: Radicals and Rational Exponents
page.contents:
Activity

If \(\sqrt[n]{a^m}\) is a real number and \(n\;\geq\;2\), then \(\sqrt[n]{a^m}\;=\;a^\frac mn\).

So radicals can be rewritten as rational exponents.

  1. With a partner, write each radical as a term with rational exponents on your own paper. Then, turn and talk to your partner.

    1. \(\sqrt[8]x\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^\frac18\)

    1. \(\sqrt[3]{x^2}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^\frac23\)

    1. \(\sqrt[11]{x^5}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^\frac5{11}\)

  1. Now, with a partner, rewrite each term as an equivalent radical.
    1. \(x^\frac12\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\sqrt[2]x\;\) or \(\;\sqrt x\)

    1. \(x^\frac17\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\sqrt[7]x\;\)

    1. \(x^\frac45\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\sqrt[5]{x^4}\;\)

Video: Learning About Rational Exponents

Watch the following video to learn more about rational exponents.

page.title: 5.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Rewriting Radicals

When writing radicals as a term with a rational exponent, the exponent becomes the numerator of the fraction in the exponent, the root or index.

In the example above, the 2 is the exponent and becomes the top of the fraction. The 5 is the index and becomes the bottom of the fraction.

Try It: Rewriting Radicals

Write \(\sqrt[6]{x^5}\) as a term with a rational exponent.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to rewrite the radical expression:


Step 1
Identify the index.
6

Step 2
Identify the exponent (inside the radical).
5

Step 3
Write the power over the root.
\(x^\frac56\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.2.4: Properties of Exponents with Rationals
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The activities you learned in a prior lesson taught you the properties of exponents. These same properties work with rational exponents.

Simplify each, and then check your answers:

  1. \({(x^2)}^\frac13\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^\frac23\)

  1. \(x^\frac23\;\cdot\;x^\frac23\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^\frac43\)

  1. \({(x^{-3})}^\frac25\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^{-\frac65}\;=\;\frac1{x^{\frac65}}\)

  1. \({(x^\frac13)}^{-1}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^{-\frac13}\;=\;\frac1{x^{\frac13}}\)

page.title: 5.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Simplify radical expressions with even and odd indexes.
  • Rewrite expressions with rational exponents as roots.
  • Use properties of exponents with rational exponents.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.2.1: Perfect Squares Revisited
    • In this activity, you were reminded of perfect squares and how they are related to repeated multiplication and square roots. You looked at which operations were equivalent and which ones were inverses of each other.
  • 5.2.2: The nth Root
    • In this activity, you analyzed what happens to negative numbers when they are raised to an odd and even power. You were also introduced to new vocabulary such as radical, index, and radicand and discovered how they are related to perfect squares and square roots.
  • 5.2.2: Self Check
  • 5.2.3: Radicals and Rational Exponents
    • In this activity, you extended radicals and root indices even further by looking at rational exponents. You rewrote expressions from radical form to rational exponent form.
  • 5.2.3: Self Check
  • 5.2.4: Properties of Exponents with Rationals
    • In this activity, you applied the properties of exponents to expressions with rational exponents. You were able to practice using the same properties of exponents from an earlier lesson.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.2.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
